importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The day the White House began demolition of the East Wing to build the new ballroom, marking the start of a major construction phase.
The date of the previous major structural addition to the White House—the Truman Balcony—establishing a benchmark for scale of current changes.
When the project was first announced, with a claimed capacity of 650 people and initial public statements about the ballroom's purpose.
The target completion date of the ballroom, before the end of President Trump’s term, indicating a timeline of political and architectural ambition.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The project is planned to be completed by January 2029, marking a key timeline for a significant structural change to the White House.

keyTakeAways: The White House is demolishing part of the East Wing to build a $250 million ballroom, despite lacking approval from the National Capital Planning Commission.
The construction is underway without federal oversight, raising concerns about regulatory compliance and transparency.
The ballroom will be 90,000 square feet and glass-walled, designed to accommodate up to 999 people, significantly expanding the capacity beyond the East Room.
President Donald Trump claims the project is privately funded by supporters and companies, with no cost to taxpayers.
Carrier Global Corp. has agreed to provide an energy-efficient HVAC system for the ballroom.
The East Wing, originally built in 1902 and renovated in 1942, will be partially torn down, with offices temporarily relocated.
Trump insists the new ballroom is a long-overdue need, citing 150 years of presidential desire and rejecting the use of South Lawn pavilions for hosting dignitaries.
The White House has not disclosed full donor information, raising questions about transparency and public accountability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has begun demolition of part of the White House East Wing to construct a $250 million, 90,000-square-foot glass-walled ballroom, despite lacking approval from the National Capital Planning Commission. The project, which will accommodate up to 999 people, is being privately funded by donors and companies such as Carrier Global Corp., which has donated HVAC systems. Trump claims the project is long overdue and necessary to replace the small East Room, which can only host about 200 people. The East Wing, originally built in 1902 and renovated in 1942, will be partially torn down, with offices temporarily relocated. The White House has not disclosed full donor information or submitted plans for review, raising concerns about regulatory compliance and transparency. The project is scheduled for completion before Trump’s term ends in January 2029.
title: Trump Begins Demolishing White House East Wing to Build $250 Million Ballroom Amid Regulatory Controversy
